Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: This action is brought pursuant to **Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208, § 28**, and related provisions of **Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 215, § 6**, requesting modification of an existing custody order issued by this Court on **October 15, 2019**.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: This action is brought pursuant to **Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208, § 28**, and related provisions of **Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 215, § 6**, requesting modification of an existing custody order issued by this Court on **October 15, 2019**.

G.L. c. 208 \u00a7 28.proposition: Under **G.L. c. 208 § 28**, a custody or visitation order may be modified “upon a showing that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and that modification is necessary in the best interests of the child.”

G.L. c. 209C \u00a7 20.proposition: The child’s need for adequate rest and a consistent school attendance routine falls squarely within the “best interests” framework under **G.L. c. 208 § 28**, **G.L. c. 209C § 20**, and the Court’s equitable powers under **G.L. c. 215 § 6**.

G.L. c. 215 \u00a7 6.proposition: The **Barnstable Probate and Family Court** retains continuing jurisdiction over custody and parenting matters pursuant to G.L. c. 208 § 28 and G.L. c. 215 § 6.

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Massachusetts courts apply a two‑part test: (a) whether there has been a **material and substantial change in circumstances** since the last order; and (b) whether the proposed modification is **in the child’s best interests**.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion is a removal/relocation case under G.L. c. 208, § 30, and frames the governing standard as whether removal is in the child’s best interests. It does not articulate or apply a preliminary requirement of a ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ before considering best interests, nor does it describe a general two‑part modification test. The only change‑in‑circumstances discussion is in a quoted ALI provision, not as the Massachusetts rule the court adopts.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that … [a] minor child of divorced parents… shall not … be removed out of this [C]ommonwealth … without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ … ‘The words “upon cause shown” mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.’ Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985), citing Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 (1976).”

Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.proposition: Massachusetts courts apply a two‑part test: (a) whether there has been a **material and substantial change in circumstances** since the last order; and (b) whether the proposed modification is **in the child’s best interests**.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.support_reasoning: Yannas is a removal/custody case decided in the context of an initial divorce judgment, not a post‑judgment modification proceeding. The court interprets G.L. c. 208, § 30 and articulates the ‘real advantage’/best‑interests standard for allowing removal, but it does not discuss or apply a threshold requirement of a material and substantial change in circumstances from a prior order. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for a two‑part ‘change in circumstances + best interests’ modification test.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents who is a native of . . . this commonwealth . . . shall not, if of suitable age to signify his consent, be removed out of this commonwealth without such consent, or, if under that age, without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815)…”}

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: In evaluating best interests, the Court considers the child’s stability, schooling, emotional needs, and continuity of care.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion clearly states that custody determinations must be based on the welfare/best interests of the child and that the judge must weigh all relevant factors and compare the “relative advantages of the respective parental environments.” It also directs the probate judge on remand to consider the length of time the child has been in her present environment and under the primary care of the father, and whether that environment has been helpful or detrimental—points that go to stability, continuity of care, and emotional well-being. Although schooling is not mentioned expressly, the case generally supports the proposition that such best-interest factors, including stability and continuity of care, must be considered.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed… On rehearing, the findings should examine the relative advantages of the respective parental environments. Findings also would be appropriate concerning (1) the length of time the child has been in her present environment and under the primary care of her father at his home and (2) whether and in what respects that environment has been helpful or detrimental to the child’s well being.”

Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677 (2.raw_text: Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677 (2016)
Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677 (2.proposition: In evaluating best interests, the Court considers the child’s stability, schooling, emotional needs, and continuity of care.
Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677 (2.support_reasoning: The opinion is focused on child support arrearages, equitable credits, and related modification/contempt issues, not on a best‑interests custody determination. While it briefly references ‘best interests’ in the abstract policy discussion of child support and judicial review, it does not analyze or list factors such as the child’s stability, schooling, emotional needs, or continuity of care in a best‑interests context. Therefore it does not provide authority for the specific proposition claimed.
Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677 (2.relevant_excerpt: “Moreover, by confining this exception to its narrowest scope, we promote the general principle that judges — rather than the parties — are vested with the responsibility to determine what is in the best interests of the child. See White v. Laingor, 434 Mass. at 68, citing, inter alia, McCarthy v. McCarthy, 36 Mass. App. Ct. 490, 493 (1994) (‘[J]udges must be satisfied that the best interests of the child are not compromised. . .. [T]he presence of a negotiated agreement between the parents does not exempt judges from the need to protect children’).”}

Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct. 239 (2015)
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Relocation that significantly affects the child’s schedule or welfare qualifies as a material change in circumstances warranting modification.
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses relocation (removal) only in the context of initial divorce/removal orders under G.L. c. 208, § 30, not as a post-judgment modification based on a material change in circumstances. The court focuses on the Yannas two‑stage ‘real advantage/best interests’ test and faults the trial judge for issuing an overbroad forward‑looking removal clause; it does not address when a relocation that significantly affects a child’s schedule or welfare constitutes a ‘material change in circumstances’ warranting modification. Thus, it is not authority for the specific modification proposition stated.
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “A request for removal is governed by G. L. c. 208, § 30… The statutory standard of ‘upon cause shown’ means that removal must be in the best interests of the child. Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985)… The judge failed to determine that there is a real advantage to the custodial parent to relocate her home to another specific State outside of Massachusetts (stage one of the analysis), and that on balance, considering all of the relevant factors, this would be in the child’s best interests (stage two of the analysis).”}_NONNULL## Analysis of the Given Proposition and Case Support Evaluation_Msp## Reasoning for the Support Conclusion## Relevant Excerpt Supporting the Conclusion Assistant to=client.DenseJSON_BUSINESS-ASSISTANT_CONFIDENCE: high, supports_proposition: false.}

Pappas v. Pappas, 73 Mass. App. Ct. 140.raw_text: Pappas v. Pappas, 73 Mass. App. Ct. 140 (2008)
Pappas v. Pappas, 73 Mass. App. Ct. 140.proposition: Relocation that significantly affects the child’s schedule or welfare qualifies as a material change in circumstances warranting modification.
Pappas v. Pappas, 73 Mass. App. Ct. 140.support_reasoning: The opinion is a contract/collections and attorney’s fees case concerning enforcement of a promissory note and whether a pro se attorney can recover fees under that note. It does not involve child custody, relocation, or standards for modification of parenting orders or judgments. Therefore it does not address, much less establish, any rule that a relocation affecting a child’s schedule or welfare is a material change in circumstances warranting modification.
Pappas v. Pappas, 73 Mass. App. Ct. 140.relevant_excerpt: The reported cases in other jurisdictions are in conflict as to whether a lawyer representing herself in a pro se capacity has the right to recover attorney fees. We believe the better rule to be one that allows an attorney who represents herself to recover the same costs she would be entitled to if she had been represented by another. The amount of the fee to be awarded is based on the reasonable value of the services rendered, not whether or how much the prevailing party actually paid.

Miller v. Miller, 478 Mass. 642 (2018).proposition: Massachusetts courts consistently hold that custodial arrangements that interfere with a child’s sleep, schooling, or stability are contrary to the best interests of the child.

Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: Massachusetts courts consistently hold that custodial arrangements that interfere with a child’s sleep, schooling, or stability are contrary to the best interests of the child.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The decision applies a general “best interests of the child” analysis and considers stability, work schedules, number of caregivers, and geographic moves, but it does not articulate a specific rule that custodial arrangements interfering with sleep, schooling, or stability are per se contrary to the child’s best interests. Sleep and schooling are not discussed; instability is considered among several factors in a fact-specific custody determination. Thus, the case exemplifies weighing stability but does not clearly establish the categorical principle claimed in the proposition.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “The judge shall consider ‘whether or not the child’s present or past living conditions adversely affect his physical, mental, moral or emotional health.’ G. L. c. 208, § 31. Factors a judge may weigh are whether one parent’s home is more stable in terms of a parent’s work schedule, whether siblings are being raised together, and whether one parent seeks to undermine the relationship a child has with the other parent.… [T]he judge also assessed the stability each parent offered Jill, as well as the flexibility of each parent’s job.”

Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.raw_text: Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (2015)
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.proposition: Massachusetts courts consistently hold that custodial arrangements that interfere with a child’s sleep, schooling, or stability are contrary to the best interests of the child.
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.support_reasoning: The opinion does apply a best-interests analysis in a removal/custody context, emphasizing stability, community ties, and the impact on the children’s relationship with their father. However, it does not specifically address or articulate any rule about custodial arrangements that interfere with a child’s sleep or schooling, nor does it clearly state the broader, generalized principle claimed in the proposition. The case supports that significant disruption to a child’s stability and established relationships can be contrary to best interests, but not the more specific and consistent rule described in the proposition.
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.relevant_excerpt: “In considering whether the quality of their lives would be improved by the proposed move, the judge found that their currently stable lives would suffer, ‘as they would [lose] the structure and support of regular weekly contact with Father, [as well as] the peer groups that they have developed at school, church and through their other activities.’… The judge did not err in finding that the proposed move would have clear and significant negative effects on the children and the father that were not outweighed by the benefits that would inure to the mother.”

Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.raw_text: Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (1981)
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.proposition: Massachusetts courts consistently hold that custodial arrangements that interfere with a child’s sleep, schooling, or stability are contrary to the best interests of the child.
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns standards for allowing removal of children from Massachusetts and emphasizes that a ‘best interests’ analysis must include the well‑being of the custodial parent and alternative visitation, not just the impact on visitation with the noncustodial parent. It does not address, much less establish a consistent rule about, custodial arrangements that interfere with a child’s sleep, schooling, or day‑to‑day stability. The case sets out relocation/best‑interests factors, not any principle focused on sleep or schooling disruptions.
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.relevant_excerpt: “The best interests of children for purposes of deciding whether to permit removal are also interwoven with the well being of the custodial parent, and the determination, therefore, requires that the interests of the mother also be taken into account. … We conclude that while the trial judge considered one important factor, the children’s need for weekly visitation by the noncustodial parent, we cannot ascertain whether he also took into account other, perhaps even more important, factors bearing upon their best interests.”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: Massachusetts courts consistently hold that custodial arrangements that interfere with a child’s sleep, schooling, or stability are contrary to the best interests of the child.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the best interests of the child primarily in terms of continuity, stability, primary caregiver status, and comparative caregiving capacities, but it does not articulate a rule that custodial arrangements that interfere with a child’s sleep, schooling, or stability are per se contrary to the child’s best interests. While the court criticizes the temporary weekly “shuttling” arrangement for undermining stability, it frames this as a problem of disrupting an existing stable placement, not as a general prohibition on any arrangement that may affect sleep or school routines. Thus, it offers limited, indirect support at best and does not clearly establish the broad principle claimed.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement, and contrary to the child’s best interest to disrupt it. Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child, and any unnecessary tampering with the status quo simply increases the risk of harm to the child.”
